moves.1. d4: My opponent starts with queen pawn, an opening that I found effective that day at school in a game against one of my friends.
moves.1... d5: I reply, mirroring my opponent, with not much experience of how to reply, I choose the most popular reply.
moves.2. e3: Blocks in the black-squared bishop, not a move that I use anymore except in gambits…
moves.2... c5: …Like the one I am playing now.
moves.3. dxc5: He takes my pawn. I have not yet figured out what is better: Capturing or protecting, in these gambit positions in the early game.
moves.3... Nc6: The next move of the gambit.
moves.4. c4: Hmmm… probably wants to prevent the double pawns on the c-file.
moves.5. Nc3: Uh-oh. Now my pawn is being threatened by my opponents pawn, his knight, and his queen.
moves.5... e6: So, naturally, I protect, also threatening the pawn with my bishop.
moves.6... Bxc5: I take the pawn, and the gambit is complete.
moves.7. cxd5: He takes my pawn, but I am well prepared for this attack.
moves.8. Bb5: Pins my knight to king. That can be annoying.
moves.8... O-O: I castle, and I am now out of the pin.
moves.9. Bxc6: Takes the knight with the bishop. I still don't which is worth more: knight or bishop.
moves.10... Qd6: I protect my pawn and threaten his knight.
moves.11... Be6: I open up my bishop. Bg4 is more attacking, but the queen can easily move out of the way.
moves.12. O-O: Castles. With the f-pawn gone the king is open to diagonals and I have the e-pawn is pinned, which can come in handy.
moves.12... Rfd8: Now that I look at it, I see that the d-5 pawn has enough protection. :D
moves.13. h3: A nothing move, should be getting out the bishop or something.
moves.13... d4: I threaten the knight, preparing for my pawn to be taken by my opponents, and then I will take back and check the king.
moves.14... Bxd4+: I take the pawn and check the king.
moves.15... Bxc3: I take the knight with my bishop.
moves.16... Rxd6: I take back, protecting my pawn on c6.
moves.17... Rad8: Doubling up rooks can be dangerous for the opponent, and I see Rd1, a swap of rooks and then I will check the king.
moves.18... Bc8: I move back in order to play Bb7, so if I want do something with my rook, My c-pawn will be protected.
moves.19... Rd6d2: I move out of the way and see that the rook and bishop could possibly meet on g2.
moves.20... Rd8d5: One of my only free squares.
moves.21. Nxc6: Takes the pawn and threatens my a-pawn threatens the pawn.
moves.21... Bb7: Now I see a possibility: 22. Na7 Ra5 or Rd8, knight or bishop retreats 23. Bg2. Checks the king and wins a rook.
moves.22. Nd4: My opponent sees the threat and retreats.
moves.23. Nf3: As I made my twenty-second move, I rejoiced… Until my opponent moved. :(
moves.23... Re2: I get out of the threat and threaten the bishop.
moves.24. Rfd1: Not a good move: Rxd1 25. Rxd1 Rxe7 26. Rd8 Re8. But I didn't see that.
moves.25. Rxd1: Takes back. obviously, but this is where I go wrong:
moves.25... h6: I could have taken the free bishop.
moves.26. Bxf6: Takes my knight, and messes up my pawns.
moves.27... Bc6: I threaten the pawn with my bishop.
moves.28... Ra2: I threaten with my rook down the a-file.
moves.29... Ra1+: I check the king with my rook.
moves.30. Kh2: Moves to the king's only free square.
moves.31. gxf3: He takes back with a pawn.
moves.33... Kg7: I threaten the rook and protect my pawn.
moves.34... f6: I push up my pawn, and now I can move my king up the g-file.
moves.35. Rc7+: Checks me, this does nothing, I was going to move my king anyway.
moves.35... Kg6: I move my king in between my two pawns, I am safe for the moment.
moves.36... Kh5: I block my opponent's king's way of escaping into my half of the board.
moves.37. c5: Pushes his pawn further, he's going for a queen.
moves.37... Ra1: I push my rook all the way to the 1st rank.
moves.38. Kh2: His king moves away from his slightly trapped position.
moves.38... Ra2+: Now, as I look at the board, I would've pushed my king to h4, but this what I played.
moves.39... Ra1: I push my rook back, hoping for three-fold repetition.
moves.40. c6: My opponent sees that there is no danger, and continues his run for a queen.
moves.42. Kg2: Threatens my rook and protects his pawn.
moves.42... Rc1: My opponent could swap pawns, but his pawn is more advanced, so it wouldn't be worth it.
moves.43. Rc8: He pushes his rook onto the 8th rank.
moves.44... a5: Now its my turn to run for it…
moves.45. c7: His rook is trapped unless he wants to give up his highly advance pawn.
moves.46. Ke1: The king is going to threat me.
moves.46... a3: But I ignore it, because the threat will do nothing.
moves.47... a2: Now, my opponent can take the rook and I get a queen. Or he can swap pawns.
moves.49. Rxa2: And he takes mine. Now its a game of few pieces.
moves.50. Ke2: Protects with the king. I can win the h-pawn.
moves.50... Kh4: I threaten the h-pawn, who has no escape.
moves.51. Ra6: So my opponent goes for a swap.
moves.52... Kg3: I threaten his pawn, and if he accepts another swap, then he will have a pawn and rook and I will have a rook.
moves.53. Rg6+: He checks me instead. A bad move. I will benefit from this.
moves.56. Ke3: He moves out of the way.
moves.57. Kf2: He moves out of the way.
moves.57... Rc2+: and I check hims yet again.
moves.58. Kg3: He moves out of the way.
moves.59. f4+: Checks me while being protected by both king and rook.
moves.59... Kg6: I retreat to my only possible square unless I want to lose a pawn.
moves.61. Ke4: Moves out of the way, and now he can push up his pawn.
moves.61... Ra3: Seeing a possible pin, I move as far away as possible.
moves.63. Ke5: Damn! It was a weak attempt which did not succeed.
moves.63... Ra5+: Now for the checking spree. Check…
moves.67. Ke5: I wanna say something different for once. But I can't think of anything else to say. Moves out of the way.
moves.68. Kf4: Moves out of the way for the second last time!
moves.69. Kg3: Moves out of the way, and now I can swap a rook for a rook.
moves.70. Kxh4: He takes back. Now its a game with VERY few pieces.
moves.70... Kg7: I move my king toward my opponent's pawn.
moves.71. Kh5: My opponent wants a draw, it looks like.
moves.72... Kxf5: And I take his. The last piece is off the board. Now only the two kings remain. The games drawn!
